news.title: Zimbabwe Sables Secure Historic Rugby World Cup Spot After Stunning Namibia
news.content:
By Sports Correspondent

KAMPALA  The Zimbabwe Sables have made history, qualifying for the 2027 Rugby World Cup after a dramatic 30-28 victory over Namibia in the Rugby Africa Cup final held in Kampala on Saturday.

In a tense and fiercely contested match, the Sables displayed remarkable resilience, tactical discipline, and unity to edge out their long-time rivals and reclaim the African crown. The win guarantees Zimbabwe the continents direct qualification spot for the upcoming World Cup in Australia.

This marks Zimbabwes first appearance at the Rugby World Cup since 1991, ending a 36-year drought and reigniting national pride in the sport.

This is a proud moment for Zimbabwean rugby, said one team official. The boys gave it their all, and their hard work and belief paid off.

The Sables journey to the final was marked by consistent performances and a growing belief that they could overcome Namibia, who had dominated African rugby for years. Saturdays final proved just how far Zimbabwe has come, with the team holding their nerve in the dying minutes to clinch a two-point win.

The result has sparked celebrations back home, with fans, former players, and officials hailing the victory as a turning point for rugby in the country.

Zimbabwe will now begin preparations for the 2027 Rugby World Cup, where they will aim to compete with the best teams on the global stage and inspire a new generation of rugby talent.

news.title: Pashor Sibanda on Advocate Chamisa: ‘He Represents Real Power and People’s Hope’
news.content:
By A Correspondent

BULAWAYO  Former Cowdray Park Member of Parliament Pashor Sibanda has reaffirmed his strong support for opposition leader Nelson Chamisa, explaining his reasons in a candid interview with Change Radio.

Responding to a question on why he continues to support Chamisa, Sibanda said the citizens leader commands authentic national backing, even in a hostile electoral environment.

Over two million Zimbabweans have consistently backed President Chamisa in 2018 and 2023, not because the system allowed it, but in spite of a rigged electoral environment, Sibanda told Change Radio. That kind of organic national support cant be cooked  its a signal that the majority of citizens see him as the legitimate alternative to authoritarian rule.

He credited Chamisa for successfully challenging ZANU PFs grip on power following the death of MDC founder Morgan Tsvangirai.

Since Tsvangirais passing, President Chamisa is the only opposition leader who has disrupted ZANU PFs hegemony and blocked them from securing a two-thirds majority. That alone has prevented further constitutional capture, he said.

Sibanda further praised Chamisa for ushering in a generational and ideological shift in Zimbabwean politics  one grounded in inclusivity.

Hes building a movement that embraces women, youth, the disabled, and every tribe and race in Zimbabwe. That vision isnt just political correctness  its the bedrock of true nation building, Sibanda emphasized.

He described Chamisa as more than just a politician, calling him a symbol of democratic resistance.

He represents a vision of Zimbabwe where power is accountable and leadership is a service, not an entitlement. Hes remained consistent in pushing for a new social contract and an economy that works for the many, not the connected few.

Concluding the interview, Sibanda said Chamisa embodies the spirit of an unfinished liberation struggle.

Not the one fought with guns, but the one were now fighting with ideas, courage and people power. He may not hold state power, but he holds the political imagination of millions  and thats where real power begins.

news.title: Resist Forced Payment of ZBC Radio Licences, Says Former MP …
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Former Masvingo Central legislator Jeffryson Chitando has urged Zimbabweans to resist what he described as state-sponsored exploitation, following the enforcement of a new law compelling motorists to pay a Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC) radio licence fee before renewing vehicle insurance or obtaining a ZINARA licence disc.

Chitando, who served under the banner of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), said the newly amended law was unjust and should be actively challenged by citizens.

Zimbabweans must resist this forced payment. It is immoral and unconstitutional to compel people to bankroll a broadcaster that serves the ruling elite while ignoring the voices of the people, he said in a statement last week.

The Broadcasting Services Amendment Act [Chapter 12:06] (No. 2 of 2025), which took effect this week, has already caused widespread outrage and confusion. Under the new law, a valid ZBC radio licence is now a mandatory requirement for accessing critical vehicle-related services.

The Zimbabwe National Road Administration (ZINARA) confirmed its compliance with the directive, stating:

ZINARA has now fully implemented the requirement in line with the Broadcasting Services Act.

But across the country, public anger is mounting. Citizens accuse the Mnangagwa-led administration of using coercion to sustain a state broadcaster that many see as partisan, out of touch, and lacking public trust.

This is nothing but a hidden tax, said a Harare motorist. We are being punished for refusing to consume propaganda. They want to make ZBC survive by force, even when no one wants to watch it.

Another resident added: Why should we be forced to pay for a service we dont use? This is extortion disguised as law.

Legal experts and civil society organisations have slammed the policy as a violation of freedom of choice and an abuse of state power.

The law sets a dangerous precedent, warned a local media watchdog. You cant compel people to fund a state media institution that fails to serve the public interest.

While government officials claim the move aligns with international broadcasting models, critics argue that the comparison is disingenuous.

In democracies, public broadcasters are funded transparently and voluntarily  not through coercive linkages to unrelated services like vehicle licensing, said one analyst.

With no exemption mechanisms in place, motorists now face a stark choice: pay the ZBC fee or forfeit their right to legally drive.

Chitando warned that the law could fuel greater unrest if not immediately repealed.

The people are already burdened by poverty and unemployment. Forcing them to fund propaganda will only inflame tensions. This must be resisted.

As the backlash intensifies, analysts say the law could become a key flashpoint in the widening rift between the Mnangagwa regime and an increasingly disillusioned citizenry.

This isnt just about cars or fees, said one commentator. Its about power, control, and a nation pushed to the edge.

news.title: Wicknell Chivayo Attends 7000 USD Boxing Bout – Blowing State Funds as Zimbabweans Suffer
news.content:
By A Correspondent

HARARE  Controversial ZANU PF-linked businessman Wicknell Chivayo is once again under fire after flaunting lavish spending abroad while Zimbabwe reels under deepening economic and social crises.

Chivayo, a known ally of President Emmerson Mnangagwa, was spotted alongside his wife Lulu enjoying premium ringside seats at the heavyweight boxing match between Oleksandr Usyk and Daniel Dubois at Wembley Stadium in London on Saturday night. Each seat reportedly cost around 5,500 (over US$7,000)  a staggering amount in a country where hospitals lack basic supplies and millions live in extreme poverty.

Usyk ultimately knocked out Dubois in the fifth round, but for many Zimbabweans, the real knockout is the image of politically connected elites living large while the nation burns.

The extravagant display has sparked fresh outrage, with critics calling it yet another example of the unchecked looting and misallocation of public funds by politically protected tenderpreneurs who profit from questionable state contracts.

Chivayo is not spending his own money. This is taxpayers money disguised through dubious tenders, said a Harare-based analyst. While ordinary people cant even afford fuel or basic medication, hes sipping champagne ringside in London.

Chivayo has long been a lightning rod for controversy. His name has been associated with massive state contracts in energy and infrastructuremost of which have failed to deliver tangible results. Despite this, he continues to live a life of obscene wealth and visibility, often posting photos online of luxury cars, designer clothes, and international trips.

Vice President Constantino Chiwenga recently coined the term Chiganandaa veiled attack on self-enriching moles within ZANU PFwidely interpreted by political watchers as a thinly disguised jab at figures like Chivayo.

The Vice President knows whats happening, said a senior government insider. The looting is blatant. But no one touches Chivayo because he has Mnangagwas protection.

As the cost of living continues to soar and basic services collapse, citizens are growing increasingly impatient with the conspicuous consumption of those close to power.

These people are looting in plain sight, said an angry vendor in Mbare. We are suffering, but theyre living like kings. Its disgusting.

With no sign of accountability or restraint from those at the top, Chivayos ringside escapade may be the latest reminder of a broader crisis.

news.title: One Dead, Another Critically Injured in Harare Fuel Tanker Explosion
news.content:
By A Correspondent A tragic accident has claimed the life of one man and left another critically injured after a fuel tanker exploded during welding work in a Harare suburb. The two individuals were reportedly unaware that the tanker had previously carried fuel, which resulted in a deadly ignition as they carried out repairs.

According to witnesses, the tanker burst into flames without warning, engulfing the workers and leaving one dead on the spot. The second victim is currently battling for his life in hospital.

Former Harare Deputy Mayor Kudzai Kadzombe expressed sorrow over the incident and called on residents to exercise greater caution and responsibility, especially in residential areas.

This is a heartbreaking and preventable tragedy, Kadzombe said. There is already a council resolution that allows for the enforcement, towing, and clamping of trucks parked in residential spaces.

She added that such trucks pose serious risks to communities.

They can cause accidents like this one, damage road infrastructure, and are often used as hiding places by criminals, particularly at night, she said.

The incident has reignited debate around the enforcement of city by-laws concerning heavy vehicles in residential zones, with many calling for stricter regulation and public awareness to prevent further loss of life.
